title: Educating national security leaders on artificial intelligence
summary:
The blog discusses a three-day custom program called "Artificial Intelligence for National Security Leaders" (AI4NSL) that aims to educate military and government leaders without technical backgrounds on the basics of artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning, and data science. The program, organized by MIT's School of Engineering, MIT Stephen A. Schwarzman College of Computing, and MIT Sloan Executive Education, brings together leaders from various branches of the US military and foreign military leaders from NATO to learn about AI and its intersection with national security.

The program was developed in response to the need for national security leaders to have a deeper understanding of AI technologies and their implications on security, warfare, and military operations. The course covers technical topics in AI and also addresses organizational challenges related to adopting AI technologies.

The curriculum includes an overview of AI concepts, such as machine learning and deep learning, as well as discussions on data, privacy, and ethical considerations. The program also focuses on organizational planning and implementation of AI technologies.

The course includes breakout sessions where participants collaborate and problem-solve together. The program emphasizes collaboration and networking among participants from different backgrounds.

The organizers of AI4NSL will continue to update the curriculum to keep up with the fast-changing landscape of AI and national security. The program aims to prepare leaders to understand the implications of AI developments for their respective units.
